metadata.title: YWC GBV Indicator Evidence Base
metadata.source: Open North Synthesis of Risk and Protective Factors (Sept 2025)

SH01.name: Number of emergency shelters in community
SH01.evidence_summary: Access to emergency shelter is consistently identified as a critical protective factor across the literature. Lack of shelter access is associated with women remaining in or returning to violent situations.
risk_factors: Long waitlists to access services (Mantler, 2024; Heggie et al., 2022)
Shelters do not reflect unique needs of rural women (Weeks, 2016)
Difficulty in keeping shelters private, hidden in RRN contexts (Zorn, 2017)
Lack of emergency housing (Moffitt, 2022; Zorn, 2017; Farhall, 2020)
protective_factors: Access to shelters / safe houses (CREVAWC, 2021; Faller, 2021; Hope et al., 2023; Jeffrey, 2019; Kardashevskaya, 2022)
Access to specialized GBV-specific services (Carter-Snell et al., 2020)
SH01.data_quality_notes: Previous surveys by Women's Shelters Canada and ESVA are well documented but primarily in PDF format. Timeliness is challenging as survey data can be one-off or funding-dependent.
SH01.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Critical infrastructure gap in northern/remote communities

SH02.name: Number of second-stage housing units in community
SH02.evidence_summary: Transitional housing is essential for survivors moving from emergency shelter to independent living. Literature identifies housing stability as a key factor in preventing returns to abusive situations.
risk_factors: Lack of affordable housing (CCSG Associates et al., 2021; Flynn, 2023; Hope et al., 2023; Maxwell, 2024; Moffitt, 2022)
Inflated housing costs due to resource development (Flynn, 2023)
Housing market pressure from short-term rentals and gentrification (Mantler, 2024)
protective_factors: Availability of safe, affordable housing options
Access to transitional housing post-shelter
SH02.data_quality_notes: HART dataset from UBC is well-maintained with good methodology. Last update 2021; next release expected 2026. Pre-pandemic data raises some reliability concerns.
SH02.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Limited housing stock in northern communities

SH03.name: Wait time to access shelter
SH03.evidence_summary: Service accessibility timing is critical during crisis. Long waitlists are documented as a barrier to safety.
risk_factors: Long waitlists to access services (Mantler, 2024; Heggie et al., 2022)
Intermittent / inconsistent services due to partial staffing (Zorn, 2017)
protective_factors: Immediate access to emergency accommodation
SH03.data_quality_notes: Requires shelter intake data. Aggregate-only access due to confidentiality. ESVA Waitlist Survey may serve as proxy.
SH03.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Extended wait times exacerbated by limited options

SH04.name: Pet-friendly shelter capacity
SH04.evidence_summary: Strong evidence that concern for animal welfare prevents women from leaving abusive situations. Pet ownership is particularly common in rural/northern contexts.
risk_factors: Dealing with or needing to house larger animals/livestock (Wuerch 2020; 2021)
Financial barriers related to caring for livestock (Giesbrecht, 2022; Wuerch, 2021)
Challenges in animal safekeeping with confidentiality concerns (Wuerch, 2021)
protective_factors: Access to pet-friendly DV shelters (Giesbrecht, 2022; Wuerch, 2021; Wuerch, 2020)
Safety planning that includes animal care (Giesbrecht, 2022)
Funding to support animal safekeeping (Wuerch, 2021)
Ability of family/friends to board animals (Wuerch, 2021)
SH04.data_quality_notes: Low quality indicator nationally - no current survey collects this specific to Yukon. Academic surveys indicate 10-20% of those experiencing homelessness have pets.
SH04.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Animals/livestock common in rural/northern contexts; major barrier to leaving

SH05.name: Distance to nearest shelter from community centre
SH05.evidence_summary: Geographic isolation is consistently identified as a risk factor. Distance to services compounds barriers for survivors in remote communities.
risk_factors: Geographical isolation (Burczycka, 2022; Faller, 2021; Farhall, 2020; Jeffrey, 2019; Kurbatfinski, 2024)
Requirement to travel long distance to access support (Flynn, 2023; Farhall, 2020)
Long emergency response times (CREVAWC, 2021)
protective_factors: Availability of travel funds to support access to services (Faller, 2021)
Close geographic distance to neighbours (Giesbrecht, 2023)
key_citations: Jeffrey et al. (2019) - Domestic Violence and Homicide in RRN Communities
SH05.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - calculable via GIS/Google Maps. Static indicator updated only when new shelters open.

SH06.name: Availability of pet-friendly rental housing
SH06.evidence_summary: Housing options for survivors with animals are limited, creating barriers to permanent relocation away from abusers.
risk_factors: Lack of pet-friendly rental housing (Giesbrecht, 2022)
protective_factors: Availability of pet-friendly rental housing (Giesbrecht, 2022)
SH06.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - estimates available from CMHC and housing authority data.
SH06.rrn_relevance: MEDIUM - Relevant where animal ownership is common

TR01.name: Existence of public transportation
TR01.evidence_summary: Transportation access is fundamental to service access. Lack of public transit in rural/remote areas severely limits options for survivors.
risk_factors: Lack of affordable and accessible transportation (Moffitt, 2022; Faller, 2021; Zorn, 2017; Farhall, 2020; CREVAWC, 2021; Pauktutiit, 2021; Youngson et al., 2021; Heggie et al., 2022)
Reliance on 'unsafe' alternative transportation methods like hitchhiking (Winnicki, 2024)
Cancellation of public transportation (Winnicki, 2024)
protective_factors: Affordable and accessible public transportation (CCSG Associates et al., 2021; Hanson, 2021; Hope et al., 2023; Jeffrey, 2019; Winnicki, 2024; Kardashevskaya, 2022)
TR01.data_quality_notes: Living wage report published yearly. Hard to apply outside Whitehorse. Community-driven research methodology.
TR01.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Most RRN communities lack public transit

TR02.name: Existence of emergency transportation options
TR02.evidence_summary: Crisis transportation that doesn't require personal vehicle ownership is essential for survivors in urgent situations.
risk_factors: Lack of year-round roads, inconsistent road conditions (Jeffrey, 2019; Zorn, 2017)
protective_factors: Local, municipal, province-led or grassroots initiatives to provide transportation (Winnicki, 2024; Saskatchewan, 2025)
Transportation policy integrating intersectional, transportation justice framework (Hanson et al., 2021; Winnicki, 2024)
TR02.data_quality_notes: Semi-public data from Victim Services and shelters. Requires direct inquiry.
TR02.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Essential where personal vehicles may not be accessible

TR03.name: Distance to nearest hospital with SANE
TR03.evidence_summary: Access to Sexual Assault Nurse Examiners is critical for forensic evidence collection within the 72-120 hour window post-assault.
risk_factors: Lack of specialized sexual violence services (Heggie et al., 2022)
Requirement to travel long distance to access support (Flynn, 2023)
protective_factors: Access to hospital-based SANE program (DuMont, 2017)
Access to community-based SANE program
Outreach to Indigenous communities on hospital-based SANE programs (DuMont, 2017)
TR03.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - SANE program locations are public knowledge. Currently only Whitehorse General Hospital in Yukon.
TR03.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Most Yukon communities require significant travel

TR04.name: Availability of travel funds for GBV services
TR04.evidence_summary: Financial support for travel is essential in contexts where services are geographically distant.
risk_factors: Financial barriers to accessing distant services
Economic burden of accessing private services (Heggie et al., 2022)
protective_factors: Availability of travel funds to support access to services (Faller, 2021)
TR04.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - varies by Nation for First Nations travel support. Semi-public from Victim Services.
TR04.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Essential for service access from remote communities

TR05.name: Number of transportation options for crisis situations
TR05.evidence_summary: Multiple transportation options increase accessibility and provide backup when primary options unavailable.
risk_factors: Limited transportation options compound isolation
protective_factors: Grassroots and local transportation options (Winnicki, 2024)
TR05.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires compilation from multiple sources.
TR05.rrn_relevance: MEDIUM - Redundancy important in RRN contexts

HC01.name: Access to SANE program
HC01.evidence_summary: SANE access is critical for both immediate healthcare and justice outcomes following sexual violence.
risk_factors: Lack of specialized sexual violence services (Heggie et al., 2022)
protective_factors: Access to hospital-based SANE program (DuMont, 2017)
Access to specialized SV services (Heggie et al., 2022)
HC01.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - program details are public.
HC01.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Currently only available in Whitehorse

HC02.name: Number of healthcare workers with IPV training
HC02.evidence_summary: Healthcare workers are often first point of contact for survivors. Training improves recognition and appropriate response.
risk_factors: Lack of specialized IPV training for healthcare workers (Rizkalla, 2020; Zorn, 2017; Montesanti, 2024; Mantler, 2022)
Use of biomedical rather than trauma and violence informed approaches (Montesanti, 2024)
protective_factors: Developing specialized IPV training for healthcare workers (Rizkalla, 2020; 2021)
Use of trauma and violence-informed care in health care settings (Mantler, 2022)
HC02.data_quality_notes: LOW reliability - training records are confidential. Would require proxy from training program data.
HC02.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Healthcare often only service available in remote areas

HC03.name: Access to primary healthcare provider
HC03.evidence_summary: Primary care access is fundamental to ongoing health support for survivors and may be the only local service available.
risk_factors: Lack of primary health care provider (Mantler, 2022)
Lack of access to health care services, general (Mantler, 2022; Heggie et al., 2022)
Reliance on walk-in clinics (Mantler, 2022)
protective_factors: Access to primary health care provider
Visiting healthcare services in remote communities
key_citations: National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) - CIHI
HC03.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - CIHI data well documented, updated quarterly. NACRS submission mandated in Yukon.
HC03.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Many remote communities rely on visiting providers only

HC04.name: Availability of trauma-informed mental health services
HC04.evidence_summary: Trauma-specialized mental health services are essential for recovery but often unavailable in RRN contexts.
risk_factors: Lack of access to mental health supports (Zorn, 2017; Mantler, 2024)
Lack of options for formal support (Wuerch, 2020; Farhall, 2020; Kurbatfinski, 2024; Youngson et al., 2021; Heggie et al., 2022)
protective_factors: Availability of formal supports for victim/survivors of violence (Weeks, 2016; Saskatchewan, 2025)
Specialized training on violence and trauma-informed approaches (Kardashevskaya, 2022; CREVAWC, 2021)
key_citations: Mental Wellness and Substance Use Services (Yukon)
HC04.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - service inventory from government is public, private practitioners require research compilation.

LJ01.name: Access to Victim Services
LJ01.evidence_summary: Victim Services provides critical support including accompaniment, information, and referrals. Access mode (in-person vs. virtual) affects service quality.
risk_factors: Lack of access to legal support (CREVAWC, 2021)
protective_factors: Availability and access to Victim Services (Faller, 2021)
Expansion of DV courts and DV options in existing courts in rural/remote areas (Saskatchewan, 2025)
LJ01.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - office locations and outreach schedules are public.
LJ01.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Service presence varies significantly by community

LJ02.name: Access to legal aid hours
LJ02.evidence_summary: Legal aid is essential for survivors navigating family court, protection orders, and custody matters.
risk_factors: Lack of access to legal support (CREVAWC, 2021)
protective_factors: Availability of legal aid / legal aid reform (Kardashevskaya, 2022; CREVAWC, 2021)
LJ02.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - allocations available from Yukon Legal Services Society (semi-public).
LJ02.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Essential for protection orders and custody matters

LJ03.name: Presence of DV-specialized court
LJ03.evidence_summary: Specialized DV courts improve outcomes by providing appropriate expertise and treatment options.
risk_factors: Standard court processes may not address DV dynamics
protective_factors: Expansion of DV courts and DV options in existing courts in rural/remote areas (Saskatchewan, 2025)
LJ03.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - DVTO court schedule and circuit court coverage are public.
LJ03.rrn_relevance: MEDIUM - Whitehorse has DVTO; check circuit coverage for other communities

LJ04.name: Access to alternative justice measures
LJ04.evidence_summary: Restorative and Indigenous justice options are critical for culturally appropriate responses, particularly in Indigenous communities.
risk_factors: Distrust in RCMP, police (Faller, 2021; DuMont, 2022; Giesbrecht, 2022; Mantler, 2024; Rizkalla, 2021; Kardashevskaya, 2022)
protective_factors: Access to restorative justice measures (Ross, 2019)
LJ04.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - varies by First Nation. Territorial program data is public.

SS01.name: Number of GBV-specific services in community
SS01.evidence_summary: Service availability is foundational to survivor support. Multiple services provide options and specialized support.
risk_factors: Poor or non-existent referral network due to lack of services (Rizkalla, 2020)
Lack of options for formal support (Wuerch, 2020; Farhall, 2020)
protective_factors: Access to specialized GBV-specific services (Carter-Snell et al., 2020)
key_citations: Yukon Status of Women Council service directory
SS01.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - service directories are public and maintained.
SS01.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Most communities have few or no GBV-specific services

SS02.name: Availability of virtual service options
SS02.evidence_summary: Virtual services can bridge geographic gaps but require technology infrastructure.
risk_factors: Poor quality internet service (Mantler, 2024)
Geographic isolation limiting in-person access
protective_factors: Using technology to bridge service gaps created by geography (Mantler, 2018; Mantler, 2024)
SS02.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - service modality can be audited directly.

SS03.name: Wait time for counselling services
SS03.evidence_summary: Timely access to counselling is critical for recovery. Long wait times can exacerbate trauma.
risk_factors: Long waitlists to access services (Mantler, 2024; Heggie et al., 2022)
protective_factors: Timely access to mental health support
SS03.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires provider survey data. Confidential aggregate only.
SS03.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Limited providers means longer waits

SS04.name: 24/7 crisis line access
SS04.evidence_summary: Round-the-clock crisis support is essential as crises don't follow business hours.
risk_factors: Lack of emergency or crisis supports
protective_factors: Availability of 24/7 crisis support
SS04.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - coverage and hours are public information.
SS04.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Note if long-distance charges apply from remote areas

EC01.name: Availability of emergency financial aid for GBV survivors
EC01.evidence_summary: Financial dependence is a major barrier to leaving. Emergency funds enable immediate safety actions.
risk_factors: Poverty (Faller, 2021), economic dependence (Kardashevskaya, 2022; CREVAWC, 2021; Youngson et al., 2021)
Financial dependence, including farming as livelihood (Farhall, 2020)
protective_factors: Access to income support programs
Availability of financial independence programs tailored to victims/survivors in RRN communities
EC01.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - varies by source (shelters, Victim Services, First Nations).
EC01.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Higher costs in RRN contexts increase need

EC02.name: Availability of relocation funds
EC02.evidence_summary: Relocation support is essential for survivors leaving abusive situations, particularly when moving away from shared community.
risk_factors: Financial barriers to relocation
Social assistance not reflective of IPV realities (Weeks, 2016; Mantler, 2024)
protective_factors: Income-support reform to reflect needs/barriers unique to IPV (Kardashevskaya, 2022)
Financial support for moving, damage deposits, rent assistance
EC02.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - program availability from Housing Corporation is public.
EC02.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Relocation often necessary in small communities

PL01.name: Policies addressing confidentiality in RRN context
PL01.evidence_summary: Small community dynamics create unique confidentiality challenges - 'everyone knows everyone' affects disclosure and service access.
risk_factors: Sense of community surveillance and judgement (Flynn, 2023; Farhall, 2020; CREVAWC, 2021)
Difficulty in keeping shelters private (Zorn, 2017)
Compromised anonymity when disclosing or accessing support (Farhall, 2020; Youngson et al., 2021; Heggie et al., 2022)
protective_factors: Conflict of interest policies unique to IPV / RRN (CREVAWC, 2021)
key_citations: Space for Action Scale (Farhall, Harris, & Woodlock, 2020)
PL01.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires policy audit. Framework is qualitative.
PL01.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Core measurement justice concern for RRN

PL02.name: Policies addressing multiple-role relationships
PL02.evidence_summary: Dual relationships are inevitable in small communities where providers may know both victim and perpetrator personally.
risk_factors: Multiple-role / confidentiality dilemmas due to small community (Rizkalla, 2020; Zorn, 2017; Montesanti, 2024)
Dual relationships (Kardashevskaya, 2022)
protective_factors: Policies to address multiple-role relationships
PL02.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires organizational policy audit.

PL03.name: GBV-specific policies in non-GBV settings
PL03.evidence_summary: Workplace and institutional policies extend protection beyond specialized services.
risk_factors: Lack of formal policies outlining specialized care for IPV victims (Mantler, 2020; Rizkalla, 2020)
protective_factors: Formalized policies to guide intersectoral collaboration (Mantler, 2022; Carter-Snell et al., 2020)

PL04.name: Level of interagency collaboration
PL04.evidence_summary: Strong collaboration improves survivor outcomes and prevents gaps in service.
risk_factors: Lack of interagency collaboration (Mantler, 2020; Rizkalla, 2020)
protective_factors: Strong interagency collaboration (Faller, 2021; Jeffrey, 2019; Mantler, 2018; Mantler, 2022; Wuerch, 2021; Wuerch, 2020; Mantler, 2017; Kardashevskaya, 2022; CREVAWC, 2021; Youngson et al., 2021; Carter-Snell et al., 2020)
key_citations: Multiple sources - most comprehensive evidence base
PL04.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires assessment of MOUs and committee participation.
PL04.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Essential where services are limited

PL05.name: Evidence of formal referral pathways
PL05.evidence_summary: Clear referral protocols reduce navigation burden on survivors and improve service coordination.
risk_factors: Poor or non-existent referral network (Rizkalla, 2020)
protective_factors: Creating effective referral pathways (Rizkalla, 2020; Mantler, 2018; Mantler, 2017; Heggie et al., 2022)
PL05.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires protocol document audit.

PL06.name: Disaster/emergency preparedness in GBV organizations
PL06.evidence_summary: COVID-19 highlighted vulnerability of GBV services to disruption. Climate emergencies increasingly relevant in north.
risk_factors: Pandemic (Moffitt, 2022; Hope et al., 2021; CREVAWC, 2021)
Natural disasters (CREVAWC, 2021)
Emergency guidelines not translated into local language (Moffitt, 2022)
protective_factors: Business continuity planning for GBV services
PL06.rrn_relevance: MEDIUM - Relevant post-COVID and with increasing wildfires

PL07.name: Workplace GBV policies in extractive industry
PL07.evidence_summary: Strong evidence links resource extraction to increased GBV risk. Workplace policies are essential preventive measure.
risk_factors: Living / working in resource extraction industry (Vector Research et al., 2022; Paukuutit, 2021; CCSG Associates et al, 2021; Hoogeveen, 2020)
Prevalence/normalization of workplace sexual violence, harassment (Vector Research et al., 2022; Paukuutit, 2021)
Lack of clear policies and reporting mechanisms (Vector Research et al., 2022; Paukuutit, 2021; CCSG Associates et al, 2021)
protective_factors: Clear policies and guidelines on reporting sexual violence/harassment in workplace (Vector Research et al., 2022; Paukuutit, CCSG Associates et al, 2021)
Public education about workplace sexual harassment (Pauktutiit, 2021; Vector et al., 2022)
PL07.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - YESAB registry provides access to policy assessments.
PL07.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Direct Yukon relevance with active mining operations

PL08.name: Data-sharing agreements between agencies
PL08.evidence_summary: Data sharing enables coordinated response and system-level analysis while respecting privacy.
risk_factors: Data gaps and/or failure to collect key information (Giesbrecht, 2023)
Poor or limited data collection methods (Giesbrecht, 2023)
protective_factors: Standardized methods of front-line agency data collection (Giesbrecht, 2023)
Legislation that allows collection of relevant risk assessment data (Saskatchewan, 2025)
PL08.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - foundational for future measurement.

WF01.name: Staff turnover in GBV sector
WF01.evidence_summary: High turnover undermines service quality and survivor trust. Workforce stability is a capacity indicator.
risk_factors: Intermittent / inconsistent services due to partial staffing, seasonal staffing (Zorn, 2017)
Staffing challenges - retention, burnout (Montesanti, 2024)
protective_factors: Resourceful leaders in GBV sector (Mantler, 2018)
WF01.data_quality_notes: LOW reliability - requires confidential workforce survey.
WF01.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Turnover particularly problematic in remote postings

WF02.name: Workforce health indicators
WF02.evidence_summary: Burnout and vacancies predict service availability. Workforce wellbeing affects service quality.
risk_factors: Staffing challenges - retention, burnout (Montesanti, 2024)
protective_factors: Workforce stability and wellbeing
WF02.data_quality_notes: LOW reliability - requires anonymous workforce survey.
WF02.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Burnout common in under-resourced northern services

WF03.name: Access to specialized GBV training
WF03.evidence_summary: Ongoing professional development maintains service quality and prevents secondary trauma.
risk_factors: Lack of specialized training (Rizkalla, 2020; Kardashevskaya, 2022)
protective_factors: Training on risk factors for IP/DH (Giesbrecht, 2023; Youngson et. al, 2021)
Other professional development opportunities (Carter-Snell et al., 2020)
WF03.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - training calendars available from HSS.
WF03.rrn_relevance: MEDIUM - Training access often requires travel

WF04.name: Clinical debriefing opportunities
WF04.evidence_summary: Structured supervision mitigates vicarious trauma in GBV workers.
risk_factors: Vicarious trauma without support structures
protective_factors: Opportunities for clinical debriefing related to GBV cases

WF05.name: Indigenous cultural safety training in healthcare
WF05.evidence_summary: Cultural safety training is essential for appropriate service delivery to Indigenous survivors.
risk_factors: Lack of specialized training in cultural safety and culturally-relevant responses to IPV (Rizkalla, 2020; Faller, 2021; Zorn, 2017; Montesanti, 2024)
protective_factors: Healthcare providers understanding unique needs of Indigenous survivors (DuMont, 2017; Rizkalla, 2021)
Specialized training on sexual violence, Indigenous survivors in health care settings (DuMont, 2017)
WF05.data_quality_notes: LOW reliability - training completions are confidential.
WF05.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Yukon Indigenous population requires culturally safe services

SQ01.name: Trauma-informed mental health services (quality)
SQ01.evidence_summary: Quality assessment goes beyond availability to actual trauma-informed practice.
risk_factors: Use of biomedical rather than trauma and violence informed approaches (Montesanti, 2024)
protective_factors: Use of trauma and violence-informed care (Mantler, 2022)
Use of victim-centred approaches (Saskatchewan, 2025)
SQ01.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Quality matters as much as availability

SQ02.name: GBV information in rural-appropriate formats
SQ02.evidence_summary: Information accessibility without internet is essential in RRN contexts where connectivity is unreliable.
risk_factors: Lack of awareness about available resources (Wuerch, 2020; Farhall, 2020; Heggie et al., 2022)
Poor quality internet service (Mantler, 2024)
protective_factors: Community education about GBV services (Mantler, 2018; Weeks, 2016)
SQ02.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - distribution methods can be audited directly.
SQ02.rrn_relevance: CRITICAL - Internet unreliable in many Yukon communities

SQ03.name: Services available in Indigenous languages
SQ03.evidence_summary: Language access is fundamental to culturally appropriate service delivery.
risk_factors: Language barriers when accessing services (Wrathall & Herron, 2021)
Language/cultural barriers (Victim factors)
protective_factors: Availability of services in language of choice
SQ03.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires service provider inquiry.
SQ03.rrn_relevance: HIGH - 8 First Nation language families in Yukon

SQ04.name: Level of service integration
SQ04.evidence_summary: Integrated services reduce navigation burden on survivors who are already in crisis.
risk_factors: Multiple contacts required to access support
protective_factors: Integration of health/social services within shelter - HUB model (Jeffrey, 2019; Mantler, 2018; Mantler, 2022)
Level of service integration
SQ04.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires key informant assessment.
SQ04.rrn_relevance: MEDIUM - Whitehorse more integrated than rural

SQ05.name: Effectiveness of Emergency Protection Orders
SQ05.evidence_summary: Legal protection only works if orders are granted and enforced.
risk_factors: Legal protections not enforced
protective_factors: Availability of Emergency Protection Orders (Faller, 2021)
EPOs that reflect understanding of unique needs (Giesbrecht, 2022)
EPOs that contain explicit descriptions of stalking behaviours (Kurbatfinski, 2024)
SQ05.data_quality_notes: LOW reliability - RCMP enforcement data requires ATIP request.
SQ05.rrn_relevance: HIGH - Enforcement challenging in remote communities

SQ06.name: Community readiness for new GBV programs
SQ06.evidence_summary: Implementation success depends on community capacity and readiness.
risk_factors: Program implementation without community readiness assessment
protective_factors: Community readiness assessment before program implementation
SQ06.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires primary research (key informant interviews).

CC01.name: Housing market pressure index
CC01.evidence_summary: Market forces (AirBnB, mining camps, speculation) affect housing availability for survivors.
risk_factors: Inflated housing costs due to resource development (Flynn, 2023)
Inflated housing due to gentrification, short-term rentals (Mantler, 2024)
protective_factors: Affordable housing availability
CC01.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - composite from multiple sources.

CC02.name: RRN-specific cost burdens
CC02.evidence_summary: Higher costs of living in RRN contexts increase financial barriers to leaving abuse.
risk_factors: Financial burdens unique to RRN communities (transportation, fuel, animal care) (Giesbrecht, 2022; Wuerch, 2021)
protective_factors: Financial support that accounts for RRN cost burdens
CC02.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - derived estimate from cost-of-living data.

CC03.name: Childcare availability
CC03.evidence_summary: Childcare access enables economic independence and workforce participation for survivors.
risk_factors: Barriers to workforce participation - childcare (Faller, 2021)
protective_factors: Accessible childcare (Faller, 2021)
CC03.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - Yukon childcare registry data available.

CC04.name: Geographic/social isolation index
CC04.evidence_summary: Isolation is a fundamental risk multiplier documented across the literature.
risk_factors: Geographical isolation (Burczycka, 2022; Faller, 2021; Farhall, 2020; Jeffrey, 2019; Kurbatfinski, 2024; Kardashevskaya, 2022; Maxwell, 2024; Hope et al., 2023; CREVAWC, 2021; Youngson, 2021)
Rurality (Farhall, 2020; Kurbatfinski, 2020; Youngson et al., 2021; Heggie et al., 2022)
Long emergency response times (CREVAWC, 2021)
protective_factors: Close geographic distance to neighbours (Giesbrecht, 2023)
CC04.data_quality_notes: HIGH reliability - composite from infrastructure data.

PE01.name: Community education campaign presence
PE01.evidence_summary: Primary prevention through education addresses root causes and community attitudes.
risk_factors: Lack of awareness about available resources (Wuerch, 2020; Farhall, 2020; Heggie et al., 2022)
Attitudes and beliefs that condone and/or minimize IPV (Kardashevskaya, 2022; Rizkalla, 2021; Letourneau, 2023; Ross, 2019; Mantler, 2018)
protective_factors: Community education campaigns about GBV (CREVAWC, 2023; Mantler, 2018; Weeks, 2016; Mantler, 2017; Saskatchewan, 2025; Kardashevskaya, 2022; Youngson et al., 2021; Wrathall & Herron, 2021)
key_citations: Federal Gender-based Violence Strategy Annual Reports
PE01.data_quality_notes: MEDIUM reliability - requires inventory of initiatives.

PE02.name: Men and boys engagement programs
PE02.evidence_summary: Engaging men and boys in prevention addresses perpetration and bystander intervention.
risk_factors: Traditional views about gender roles (Flynn, 2023; Faller, 2021; Farhall, 2020; Jeffrey, 2019)
Misogynistic attitudes (perpetrator factor)
protective_factors: Programming that engages men and boys (Ross, 2019; Wrathall & Herron, 2021)
key_citations: PMC study on engaging men in gender equality (2023)
PE02.data_quality_notes: LOW reliability - relatively rare programs; small sample in existing research.
